articles.headline: Piling Sand in a Disputed Sea, China Literally Gains Ground
articles.snippet: Satellite photos show the speed, scale and ambition China has exerted to assert ownership over South China Sea islands, far from the mainland.
articles.abstract: Satellite photos show the speed, scale and ambition China has exerted to assert ownership over South China Sea islands, far from the mainland.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The clusters of Chinese vessels busily dredge white sand and pump it onto partly submerged coral, aptly named Mischief Reef, transforming it into an island.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Sex Education in Europe Turns to Urging More Births
articles.snippet: Disconcerting forecasts showing aging populations and increasing burdens on social services are weighing on governments throughout the region.
articles.abstract: Disconcerting forecasts showing aging populations and increasing burdens on social services are weighing on governments throughout the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Twenty-five Danish 13- and 14-year-olds gathered in a circle to talk about sex. This was going to be awkward.

articles.headline: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev Is Guilty on All 30 Counts in Boston Marathon Bombing
articles.snippet: The verdicts set the stage for a second, more contentious phase of the trial in which the same jury will decide whether to sentence him to life in prison or death.
articles.abstract: The verdicts set the stage for a second, more contentious phase of the trial in which the same jury will decide whether to sentence him to life in prison or death.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In the silent well of Courtroom Nine, a clerk read out the jury’s verdicts: Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. The word echoed in the courtroom as the clerk pronounced it 30 times, once for each of 30 main counts.

articles.headline: Fed Policy Makers Seem Cool to Rate Increase in June
articles.snippet: Minutes of the March policy meeting, and recent comments by Federal Reserve officials, reflect concern that job and inflation goals are unmet.
articles.abstract: Minutes of the March policy meeting, and recent comments by Federal Reserve officials, reflect concern that job and inflation goals are unmet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is looking increasingly unlikely to start raising its benchmark interest rate in June.

articles.headline: Mark Pincus, Zynga’s Founder, Returns as C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Mark Pincus succeeds Don Mattrick, the former Electronic Arts executive who was brought in less than two years ago to lead the online game company.
articles.abstract: Mark Pincus succeeds Don Mattrick, the former Electronic Arts executive who was brought in less than two years ago to lead the online game company.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Mark Pincus hired a new executive to run Zynga, the online game company he founded, he wrote on Twitter, calling the executive, Don Mattrick, an “Internet treasure.”
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Seeing Path to Justice in Video of Shooting on Bystander’s Phone
articles.snippet: When a man approached Walter Scott’s family with the video, what might have been another shooting of a black man by the police suddenly became an astonishing glimpse of life and death.
articles.abstract: When a man approached Walter Scott’s family with the video, what might have been another shooting of a black man by the police suddenly became an astonishing glimpse of life and death.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — It was at a vigil Sunday for his slain brother that Anthony Scott found out what he had believed was true all along.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: I.R.S. Shortcut to Tax-Exempt Status Is Under Fire
articles.snippet: The agency introduced the application last year to ease a backlog of cases, but critics say the process is now so easy that it invites fraud.
articles.abstract: The agency introduced the application last year to ease a backlog of cases, but critics say the process is now so easy that it invites fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Battered by a scandal over delays in approving groups for tax-exempt status and plagued by a backlog tens of thousands of cases long, the Internal Revenue Service unveiled a strikingly stripped-down online application last year to speed the process.

articles.headline: Obama Calls for End to ‘Conversion’ Therapies for Gay and Transgender Youth
articles.snippet: President Obama condemned a practice that is promoted as a way to help people change their sexual orientation.
articles.abstract: President Obama condemned a practice that is promoted as a way to help people change their sexual orientation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A 17-year-old transgender youth, Leelah Alcorn, stunned her friends and a vast Internet audience in December when she threw herself in front of a tractor-trailer after writing in an online suicide note that religious therapists had tried to convert her back to being a boy.

articles.headline: Video of Walter Scott Shooting Reignites Debate on Police Tactics
articles.snippet: Videos of police shootings have spurred calls for more officers to use cameras, raising questions about how much the justice system can rely on the accounts of police officers.
articles.abstract: Videos of police shootings have spurred calls for more officers to use cameras, raising questions about how much the justice system can rely on the accounts of police officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nothing has done more to fuel the national debate over police tactics than the dramatic, sometimes grisly videos: A man gasping “I can’t breathe” through a police chokehold on Staten Island, a 12-year-old boy shot dead in a park in Cleveland. And now, perhaps the starkest video yet, showing a South Carolina police officer shooting a fleeing man in the back.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: When a Plane Seat Next to a Woman Is Against Orthodox Faith
articles.snippet: Airline passengers are sharing stories of conflicts between ultra-Orthodox Jewish men trying to follow their faith by avoiding mixed-sex seating and women just hoping to sit down.
articles.abstract: Airline passengers are sharing stories of conflicts between ultra-Orthodox Jewish men trying to follow their faith by avoiding mixed-sex seating and women just hoping to sit down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Francesca Hogi, 40, had settled into her aisle seat for the flight from New York to London when the man assigned to the adjoining window seat arrived and refused to sit down. He said his religion prevented him from sitting beside a woman who was not his wife. Irritated but eager to get underway, she eventually agreed to move.

articles.headline: The Gap Between Auto Dealers and Social Media
articles.snippet: Carmakers embrace social media and spend millions of dollars on sophisticated marketing campaigns, but many dealers barely maintain a Facebook page.
articles.abstract: Carmakers embrace social media and spend millions of dollars on sophisticated marketing campaigns, but many dealers barely maintain a Facebook page.
articles.lead_paragraph: Matt Howell, the general manager of a Hyundai dealership in Huntsville, Tex., has been in the auto business for 18 years. In all that time, he said, “I can think of one deal that originated on Facebook.”

articles.headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Says Sanctions Must Lift When Nuclear Deal Is Signed
articles.snippet: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, declared on Thursday that all sanctions would have to be lifted on the day any deal is signed and that military sites would be strictly off limits to foreign inspectors.
articles.abstract: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, declared on Thursday that all sanctions would have to be lifted on the day any deal is signed and that military sites would be strictly off limits to foreign inspectors.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader on Thursday challenged two of the United States’ bedrock principles in the nuclear negotiations, declaring that all economic sanctions would have to be lifted on the day any final agreement was signed and that military sites would be strictly off limits to foreign inspectors.
articles.byline: By Thomas Erdbrink and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Scientists Question Environmental Impact of China’s Winter Olympics Bid
articles.snippet: According to Beijing’s bid, the impact from the Games would be “eco-friendly.” But conservationists say that holding the Games in a water-stressed environment would be devastating.
articles.abstract: According to Beijing’s bid, the impact from the Games would be “eco-friendly.” But conservationists say that holding the Games in a water-stressed environment would be devastating.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIUZHANBAO, China — A few times a year, rains sprinkle the dry mountains north of Beijing, feeding streams that trickle down to catchments like the Yunzhou Reservoir. From its shores, the water shimmers and sparkles, a mirage that local farmers can see but not touch.
